description:
Saitama has a rather peculiar hobby, being a superhero, but despite his heroic deeds and superhuman abilities, a shadow looms over his life. He's become much too powerful, to the point that every opponent ends up defeated with a single punch.

The lack of challenge has driven him into a state of apathy, as he watches his life pass by having lost all enthusiasm, at least until he's unwillingly thrust in the role of being a mentor to the young and revenge-driven Genos.
synonyms: วันพันช์แมน

tags.name: Superhero
tags.description: Prominently features super-powered humans who aim to serve the greater good.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Parody
tags.description: Features deliberate exaggeration of popular tropes or a particular genre to comedic effect.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Satire
tags.description: Prominently features the use of comedy or ridicule to expose and criticise social phenomena.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Surreal Comedy
tags.description: Prominently features comedic moments that defy casual reasoning, resulting in illogical events.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Cyborg
tags.description: Prominently features a human character whose physiological functions are aided or enhanced by artificial means.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Kaiju
tags.description: Prominently features giant monsters.

tags.name: Seinen
tags.description: Target demographic is adult males.

tags.name: Aliens
tags.description: Prominently features extraterrestrial lifeforms.

tags.name: Cultivation
tags.description: Features characters using training, often martial arts-related, and other special methods to cultivate qi (a component of traditional Chinese philosophy, described as "life force") and gain strength or immortality.

tags.name: Primarily Male Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Yuri
tags.description: Prominently features romance between two females, not inherently sexual. Also known as Girls' Love.

tags.name: Martial Arts
tags.description: Centers around the use of traditional hand-to-hand combat.

tags.name: Demons
tags.description: Prominently features malevolent otherworldly creatures.

tags.name: Henshin
tags.description: Prominently features character or costume transformations which often grant special abilities.

node.description:
**[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ONE_rakugaki)** | **[Website](http://galaxyheavyblow.web.fc2.com/)**

One (often stylized as ONE) is a manga artist, best known as the author and creator of [One-Punch Man](https://anilist.co/manga/85364/One-Punch-Man/) and [Mob Psycho 100](https://anilist.co/manga/85189/Mob-Psycho-100/).

He grew up in Konosu, Saitama, and started getting interested in manga when his parents bought him [Crayon Shin-chan](https://anilist.co/manga/32435/Crayon-Shinchan/). ONE also made several manga in the past that never got serialized such as "Sun Man" and "Tennis Player Ryu".

ONE started releasing One-Punch Man on his own website under no official publisher. [A web version](https://anilist.co/manga/74347/One-PunchMan/) was later serialized by Weekly Young Jump with [Yusuke Murata](https://anilist.co/staff/96903/Yusuke-Murata) as the artist. Mob Psycho 100 was serialized in Ura Sunday, the online version of Weekly Shonen Sunday.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/NEBU_KURO)

He was once the assistant and apprentice of Takeshi Obata of _Hikaru no Go_ and _Death Note_ fame. He had a number of one-shots published in Weekly Shonen Jump, namely _Partner_ (won the 122nd Hop*Step award), _Samui Hanashi_ (won the 2nd Prize in the 51st Akatsuka Award), _Kaitou COLT_, and of course, _Eyeshield 21_ (began serialization in Weekly Shonen Jump No. 34 2002).

He is also responsible for designing Dust Man from _Rockman 4_ and Crystal Man from _Rockman 5_.

Originating from [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/). Went through [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/) and [Shin-Ei](https://anilist.co/studio/247/) before going freelance. He is most known for his work on the first season of [One Punch Man](https://anilist.co/anime/21087/OnePunch-Man/). He is also the original creator of original anime [Sonny Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/132126/Sonny-Boy/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/2256470167)

After graduating from high school, Kubota went through training at [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/)'s research center before dropping out and joining [Xebec](https://anilist.co/studio/27/) in 1998. Three years later in he met [Sushio](https://anilist.co/staff/103619/) at Comiket, which led to Kubota joining [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/). There he made his debut as an animation director on the premiere of [Mahoromatic](https://anilist.co/anime/277/)'s second season.

In 2005, he made his debut as a character designer, although still jointly together with Sushio and [Takaaki Yamashita](https://anilist.co/staff/110187/), on the 6th [One Piece](https://anilist.co/anime/464/) movie. The film was directed by Mamoru Hosoda, which led to Kubota getting an invite to join the production of [The Girl Who Leapt Through Time](https://anilist.co/anime/2236/) as an animation director. After this he kept working at Gainax until going freelance.

In 2012, he worked as the main character designer on [From the New World](https://anilist.co/anime/13125/) and [Robotics;Notes](https://anilist.co/anime/13599/), and a few years later he served as one on [One-Punch Man](https://anilist.co/anime/21087/), which earned him international fame.

JAM Project ("JAM" standing for "Japan Animationsong Makers") is an anime music genre (or anison) "supergroup" based in Japan, originally founded on July 19, 2000 by famous 1970s theme song artist Ichirou Mizuki. The group is composed of many vocal artists well known in the genre; aside from the many anime and video game theme songs that this group has performed together, each member is famous for their own solo performances of anime-related music.  As a group, they are perhaps best known for their themes for the Super Robot Wars series of video games.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/makoto_myzk) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/宮崎誠)

A music creator for the creative music unit [(K)NoW_NAME](https://anilist.co/staff/126602/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/bahijd) | [Tumblr](http://bahijd.tumblr.com/) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/bahijd)

Freelance animator from Austria who gained attraction on the internet thanks to his gif animations, which then served as a stepping stone for him joining the industry. Made his proper debut on [Shinichirou Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/97009/)'s adaptation of [Kids on the Slope](https://anilist.co/anime/12531/). His cuts are often heavily layered, exploiting the unique potential of digital processing.

**Notable works outside anime:**
- Skullgirls (Video Game, 2012) (Character and Effects Animation)
- Carpainter - Digital Harakiri (Music Album, 2015) (Cover Illustration)
- Death Stranding (Video Game, 2019) (Concept Art)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/sekise10) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=yutaka_nakamura) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/中村豊_(アニメーター%29)

Yutaka Nakamura graduated from Yoyogi Animation Gakuin and first joined studio Ad Cosmo. After switching several studios; from Art Office Sharaku, to Anime Torotoro, to [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), he eventually settled at [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/) with a contract.

Nakamura is considered to be among the best action animators, with his scenes featuring catchy movement and effects. Some of his recognizable traits include camera shaking, blurs, and bending and stretching high-speed objects. His fights are praised for its weighty, intense choreographies that are heavy on impact frames. His signature trait is drawing debris as simple cubes, consequentially named "Yutapon Cubes," which are stylistic and easy to draw. Despite being responsible for popularizing it, Nakamura has stated that he started doing it when he noticed [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/) doing it. 

(Source: Animators Wiki)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/前田真宏_(アニメ監督%29)

A prominent anime creator and one of the founders of studio [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/).

While still in university, Maeda was part of a manga club together with [Yoshiyuki Sadamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/98158/), during which both of them got invited to participate on [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) and [Daicon IV](https://anilist.co/anime/121664/). This brought Maeda enough recognition to get invited on the production of [Nausicaä](https://anilist.co/anime/572/), and the subseqeunt late '80s [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) films. He also worked on [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/)'s projects during this time.

In 1992, after having completely cut ties with Ghibli due to differences in working methods, Maeda founded Gonzo together with [Shinji Higuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/107646/), [Hiroshi Yamaguchi](https://anilist.co/staff/97308/) and [Shouji Murahama](https://anilist.co/staff/119708/), who were Gainax employees he had previously worked with on [The Wings of Honneamise](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/) and [Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water](https://anilist.co/anime/1251/). At Gonzo he debuted as a director in 1998 with [Blue Submarine No.6](https://anilist.co/anime/1051/).

In 2004, Maeda directed [Gankutsuou](https://anilist.co/anime/239/), an adaptation of an 1844 novel, The Count of Monte Cristo, by [Alexandre Dumas](https://anilist.co/staff/102535/). Initially Maeda wanted to adapt an Alfred Bester novel, The Stars My Destination, but was rejected by the novel's copyright holders after proposing the numerous changes he wanted to make to the original narrative. He then searched for another work he could adapt into a science fiction setting and ended up going with The Count of Monte Cristo. The series was praised by Western critics and received multiple international accolades.

Called one of the most imaginative visualists in anime by Helen McCarthy, a British anime reference book author.

Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

Known to have been a close friend of [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)'s before his passing.
Shouji Hata is an Audio Engineer.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/2256470167)

After graduating from high school, Kubota went through training at [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/)'s research center before dropping out and joining [Xebec](https://anilist.co/studio/27/) in 1998. Three years later in he met [Sushio](https://anilist.co/staff/103619/) at Comiket, which led to Kubota joining [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/). There he made his debut as an animation director on the premiere of [Mahoromatic](https://anilist.co/anime/277/)'s second season.

In 2005, he made his debut as a character designer, although still jointly together with Sushio and [Takaaki Yamashita](https://anilist.co/staff/110187/), on the 6th [One Piece](https://anilist.co/anime/464/) movie. The film was directed by Mamoru Hosoda, which led to Kubota getting an invite to join the production of [The Girl Who Leapt Through Time](https://anilist.co/anime/2236/) as an animation director. After this he kept working at Gainax until going freelance.

In 2012, he worked as the main character designer on [From the New World](https://anilist.co/anime/13125/) and [Robotics;Notes](https://anilist.co/anime/13599/), and a few years later he served as one on [One-Punch Man](https://anilist.co/anime/21087/), which earned him international fame.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/池田繁美)

Founder and representative director of Atelier Musa.

Originating from [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/). Went through [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/) and [Shin-Ei](https://anilist.co/studio/247/) before going freelance. He is most known for his work on the first season of [One Punch Man](https://anilist.co/anime/21087/OnePunch-Man/). He is also the original creator of original anime [Sonny Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/132126/Sonny-Boy/).

Originating from [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/). Went through [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/) and [Shin-Ei](https://anilist.co/studio/247/) before going freelance. He is most known for his work on the first season of [One Punch Man](https://anilist.co/anime/21087/OnePunch-Man/). He is also the original creator of original anime [Sonny Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/132126/Sonny-Boy/).
